block.p: SOME puppets simply tug at your heartstrings. Others tackle more serious subjects. The marionettes shown here confront religion, AIDS and celebrity worship, among other topics. Ronnie Burkett's Theater of Marionettes production, ''Street of Blood,'' will be staged at the New York Theater Workshop as part of the Henson International Festival of Puppet Theater.

The festival, held every other year, was first held in in 1992, and is kicking off its fifth season, with the largest assemblage of puppet troupes ever presented in New York. Some 26 companies from around the world will perform on 14 stages during two and a half weeks, offering work by 146 artists. Performances are for both at adults and children. A ''For Kids'' series featuring a free performance on Saturday of Batoto Yetu, a children's dance troupe, at the Bronx Museum of the Arts. Cheryl Henson, executive producer of the festival, has been involved in puppetry most of her life. Her father, Jim Henson, created the Muppets.
